intro: Acacia hastulata, commonly known as the slender wattle, is a shrub native to Australia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its feathery, bipinnate leaves. The plant produces yellow globular flowers that bloom in spring, attracting various pollinators. Its seed pods are elongated and contain small, hard seeds. Acacia hastulata is often used in ecological restoration due to its ability to thrive in arid and semi-arid environments.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees commonly known as wattles, native to Australia and other parts of the world. Its species is Acacia hastulata, a specific type of acacia known for its distinctive leaf shape and is native to certain regions of Australia.

This plant thrives in well-drained soils and is often associated with dry, open habitats. It is a shrub or small tree that plays an important role in local ecosystems. It has since spread beyond cultivation and is now considered an environmental weed in several regions of southern Australia. The plant thrives in a variety of soil types but is particularly common in disturbed areas such as roadsides and agricultural land.
